I__Òve come up with some rules to guide my #aha2015 decisions. First, professional development always trumps content-based papers.
Second, methodological/big-picture interpretive frames trump  traditional sessions. #aha2015
Third, sessions featuring the work of people I know are a low priority. I__Òll socialize w/ them, using sessions for new people. #aha2015
And finally, in the event of a tie, sessions in the same hotel as the previous session win! #aha2015
As I craft my #aha2015 schedule, I'm finding myself drawn to labor issues/pedagogy/methodology panels than traditional/big name panels.

Kazin: People don't go into history to "demolish" this or that interpretation. Do it because they love something about the past. #aha2015
Foner:  Can't wait for the Obama administration to end.  It has been awful for education and especially the teaching of history. #AHA2015
Question from floor:  Does being a public intellectual imply some degree of privilege? #AHA2015
Kazin gives advice from his literary agent: "Don't assume interest." #AHA2015
Peniel Joseph: If you can't write a twitter post you can show to your mother, don't tweet  it. Too many angry tweeters.  #AHA2015
I can definitely relate to these "regret" stories from public intellectuals. http://www.uminnpressblog.com/2012/03/they-came-for-john-fea.html»___™ I still stand by my piece. #AHA2015
Kazin regrets writing a five article series on the greatness of North Korea. Wrote it "as a young man." #aha2015
@TenuredRadical When you write as a public intellectual, consider whether you want to deal with the attacks.  It is worth it? #aha2015
Foner: Regrets writing piece in forum on "Was George W. Bush" the worst president in history.  He argued "yes." Too ahistorical.   #AHA2015
Kazin:  Conservatives like to fund ideas.  Liberals like to fund activism. #AHA2015
Zelizer:  He is more of a "commentator" public intellectual as opposed to an "activist" PI. Fits better with his role as historian.#AHA2015
Zelizer:  Conservatives are in a better position to be public intellectuals because they believe liberals control the academy. #AHA2015
Question: Do the conservative public intellectuals function differently from liberal public intellectuals? #AHA2015
@TenuredRadical: As public intellectuals, when we "put history out there" it has consequences. #AHA2015
Kazin:  Even if the movie is inaccurate it can still create a conversation about a subject that no one was talking about before. #aha2015
Foner: If you think you can get rich working with movie-makers, forget it. #AHA2015
@TenuredRadical Movie producers want historians to do a lot of work for free.  Be careful when they call.  #aha2015
Foner: Shakespeare never went on TV saying that everything in "Julius Caesar" was true. #aha2015
@TenuredRadical: Editors have told her that they don't like working with academics because they can't synthesize ideas. #AHA2015
@TenuredRadical : Just because someone wants a public audience, they may not always get the audience that they want. #AHA2015
Claire Potter, the @TenuredRadical, is now up.  Talking about academic blogging. #aha2015
My daughter, currently taking AP US History and reading Foner, just recognized his name from my tweets.  I just became a cool Dad! #aha2015
Kazin: Wish he had a tape recorder when lunching with Rove to record all the negative things he said about American evangelicals. #AHA2015
Kazin: Karl Rove wrote him note praising his WJ Bryan book and asked him to lunch. Had a great discussion about American biography. #aha2015
Kazin: Writes for the public out of political convictions, personal history of activism (in Cuba and elsewhere) and pure ego. #AHA2015
Kazin:  First heard term "public intellectual" from Jacoby's book. There are some good public intellectuals on the left and right. #AHA2015
Peniel: American culture is not just anti-intellectual, but anti-historical.  Depth of historical context necessary to know world. #AHA2015
Peniel:  Historians must become public intellectuals because it is essential for democracy. #AHA2015
Peniel: Scholarship and public work are inseparable. Do we want to be public intellectuals for our careers, or to make change? #aha2015
Foner is not giving up on scholarship as a way of making more just and humane society. Uses his book on Reconstruction as example. #aha2015
Foner: In today's capitalist society, taking an hour to read a history book is hard to justify.  This is a problem.  #aha2015
I have always liked how Foner pronounces the word "histaarical"  #aha2015
Foner:  "I have given up on historical documentaries." Can't distill the complexity of a historical event in a television show.  #aha2015
Foner:  "When I write for *The Nation* I write with a different hat than I do when I am writing a scholarly book." #AHA2015
Foner:  Must resist huge temptation to use history instrumentally to fit an immediate legal issue.  #AHA2015
Foner has spoken to the public, consulted on museum exhibits, testified in court.  Some have been successful, some have not #AHA2015
Foner: Anyone can be a public intellectual. Just need cell phone. Is this good or does it represent the collapse of civilization? #AHA2015

Goldsmith: When it comes to history, readers still prefer books over e-books #AHA2015
Goldsmith: Knopf publishes 30 hard covers a year in history. 50% by journalists and 50% by historians. Hasn't changed in 10 years.  #aha2015
Goldsmith: Primary market for Knopf history: white men with money.  That doesn't last long, so academic market always in mind. #aha2015
Keith Goldsmith now up:  Knopf/Doubleday and Vintage books.  Works with Lepore, Jasanoff, Bailyn, others.  #AHA2015
Jarrad: "Academic reviews take forever to come out."  Yes.  But if you want to reach public with your book should you really care? #AHA2015
Jarrad:  U Press authors need to be tireless in promoting books.  Academic presses lean heavily on social media for marketing. #aha2015
Jarrad:  Academic presses market mostly toward libraries and Amazon. #AHA2015
Mary Beth Jarrad is up.  She is at NYU Press and is representing academic markets.  Academics in room breathing a sigh of relief.  #aha2015
@markcheathem  I am guessing that most of the people in the room feel the same way.  It's seem to be all journalism. #aha2015
Gentile's talk is basically about how to write books like Laura Hildrebrand, Jon Meacham, and Tracy Kidder.   #AHA2015

Gentile discussing academic marketing.  Wants to know how a given book proposal will force historians to "change their syllabus." #AHA2015
Michael Gentile of Random House is now up.  Responsible for history at Crown, Random House, Penguin  #AHA2015

Question from floor: Are history majors declining because the curriculum is too demanding or rigorous?  Should we make it easier?  #AHA2015
Comment from floor: History depts with minors and certificate programs can better "weather the storm" of declining enrollments. #AHA2015
@wcaleb History teaches "habits of the mind" that are unique to the major,  just as other disciplines teach other habits. #AHA2015
I like that @wcaleb is a disciplinary thinker. Interdisciplinary does not teach students how to think in a particular way. #aha2015
@wcaleb complete comments can be found here: http://wcm1.web.rice.edu/history-major-in-digital-age.html»___™ #aha2015
@wcaleb Perhaps most importantly,history majors must "do history." Must become "creators."  Digital hist. in curriculum does this.  #aha2015
@wcaleb Moving toward the digital in the history major is "necessary."  Students need to critically engage with things online. #aha2015
@wcaleb Calls for history majors to bring digital projects into the capstone experience.  Move beyond the standard research paper  #AHA2015
Did I mention that @messiahcollege history department gets a nice plug in this American Scholar essay?: https://theamericanscholar.org/habits-of-mind/»_  #AHA2015
@wcaleb reflets on Grafton and Grossman *American Scholar* essay on teaching historical research: https://theamericanscholar.org/habits-of-mind/»_ #aha2015
Caleb McDaniel of Rice U. is now up. #AHA2015  His comments will connect digital history and "tuning" of history departments.
Kinkela: Fredonia Hist. Dept. no longer the "problem child" on campus. The AHA tuning project helped them connect across campus . #AHA2015
Kinkela:  Connect w/ campus career and internship center to help history students think about what they can do with major.  #AHA2015
Kinkela:  Fredonia history graduates wanted more education on how their history major connects with real life, careers, etc... #AHA2015
Kinkela:  Part of the "tuning" process requires that we tell student stories and make them available to administrators.  #aha2015
Kinkela:  History Dept. at Fredonia gains social capital by connecting to Fredonia's "baccalaureate goals" for all students.  #AHA2015
Kinkela:  AHA Tuning Project has helped department think more about learning than about teaching.  #AHA2015
Kinkela: Need to think about what history majors need to learn and when in their program should they be learning it?  #AHA2015
Kinkela: History teacher major at Fredonia is drastically declining due to declining number of children in the region. #AHA2015
David Kinkela is now up.  Teaches history at SUNY-Fredonia.  #AHA2015
Hyde: Got some psychology majors to take history courses because they heard that history courses were teaching "empathy" in class. #AHA2015
Very surprised that there is not a historical research or methods course in the history dept. at a place like Colorado College. #aha2015
Hyde: Colorado College history majors were weak on research skills, historiographical thinking, and connecting past to present. #aha2015
Hyde now passing out her history department assessment report from Colorado College. Ouch!  #aha2015
Hyde: Working on connecting current history majors with history alums at Colorado College.  Added stories of connection to website. #aha2015
Hyde: Most Colorado College history alums working in government, lawyers, business.  #AHA2015
Hyde: Through survey found history alums were very positive. Few working in history.  Most went to grad school. but took time off. #AHA2015
Hyde: Sent survey to all the history alum of Colorado College since 1940.  Sent to 2600 people, got 400 back. #AHA2015
Hyde:  Never told her colleagues she was doing "tuning."  Needed to woo the unwilling colleagues to buy into changes. #AHA2015
Hyde:  Got involved in AHA tuning project.  How do we change curriculum to make strengthen the major?  #aha2015
Hyde:  Assessment and the cost at Colorado College (60K) forced history department to think about what a history major offers. #AHA2015
Hyde: Thought dropping history enrollments across country wouldn't affect Colorado College because it was elite LA college.  Wrong. #aha2015
Hyde:  At Colorado College assessment came in 2010.  It was the visitor that never left. #AHA2015
Anne Hyde of Colorado College is opening up the session "Wither the History Major."  #AHA2015
